You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: The state of Rajasthan is in the north-west of India, and running through it from north- east to south- west is a ridge of very old rocks, which form the Aravalli Range. To the north-west of this Range the area is very dry, and it falls gradually towards the Indus Valley. This very large area between the Aravalli Range and the plain forms the Thar Desert. Its annual rainfall is very low, usually less than 250 mm. Moreover, it is very irregular, and falls mainly during sudden storms. Although this figure is higher than in the Indus Valley, there are no large rivers which can be used for irrigation. Because of this, it remains a sandy wasteland, with bare hills and waterless valleys. The ground is often completely bare of vegetation, though in some places a few bushes or plants can be seen. The desert has only a very few inhabitants. Sometimes a village is started where, for a time, there is a little water and some millet can be grown. But when the water runs out, the villagers have to leave and move somewhere else. Some people own camels, which they use to carry on trading in the region, but travelling across the desert has always been made difficult by the lack of water. In spite of this, there are some towns: Jaisalmer is an important centre for such trading routes, and Bikaner is famous for the goods which it makes from the camel hair and cotton.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Water Pollution: Over two third of Earth's surface is covered by water ; less than a third is taken up by land. As Earth's population continues to grow, people are putting ever-increasing pressure on the planet's water resources. Our oceans, rivers, and other water bodies are being "squeezed" by human activities—not so they take up less room, but so their quality is reduced. Poorer water quality means water pollution. With billions of people on the planet, disposing of sewage waste is a major problem. The population of Britain produces around 300 million gallons of sewage every day. Some of it still pumped untreated into the sea through long pipes. Sewage contains all kinds of other chemicals. When people are sick with viruses, the sewage they produce carries viruses into the environment. It is possible to catch illnesses such as hepatitis, typhoid, and cholera from river and sea water. Farms often use large amounts of herbicides and pesticides, both of which are toxic pollutants. These substances are particularly dangerous to life in rivers, streams and lakes, where toxic substances can be built up over a period of time. Farms also frequently use large amount of chemical fertilizers that are washed into the waterways and damage the water supply and the life within it. Fertilizers can increase the amount of nitrates and phosphates in the water.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: THE MEASUREMENT OF ASTRONOMICAL DISTANCES: The measurement of astronomical distances seems like a conjuring trick: they are so enormous that they fill us with astonishment. How can men know how far away the stars are? Yet like a conjuring trick it all seems very obvious when we know how it is done. The methods of measurement are indeed very ordinary. Perhaps the most important is essentially the method that the driver of a car uses at night to judge the distance of an approaching car. If the other car’s headlights are very bright, he judges that it is; close; if they are rather dim, he decides that is far away. But if the other cars headlights are especially bright or especially dim, the estimated distance will be wrong. A correct judgement therefore depends on knowing how bright normal headlights would be at some standard distance-say, 100 meters. Now if we tried to use just any stars as ‘headlights’ for determining astronomical distances, we should immediately run into serious trouble , because the true brightness’s of the stars vary very much more than those of the headlights of cars. Hence, if the headlight’ method is employed , only those stars must be used whose true brightness’s are accurately known. Stars like the sun could be used but these would have two big disadvantages. First, the Sun is not very bright, so it is not easy to see other stars of the same kind when they are far away. And second , a great deal of searching would have to be done to pick out these particular stars. Both these disadvantages are overcome, however, by using stars known as RR Lyrae* as ‘headlights’. Their true brightness’s are all about 100 times greater than the Sun, and they also have a characteristic type of oscillation which allows them to be detected easily. Thus to measure the distance of an RR Lyrae star, it is first photographed for a fixed period of time. Its apparent brightness can then be estimated from the degree to which it affects the photographic plate. From this figure and its known true brightness, the distance of the star can then be calculated. The calculation requires the use of the optic law which states that the apparent intensity of any source of light decreases as the inverse square of its distance.

You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: The trees are great donors, they keep giving their services whether in the form of fruits, flowers, medicines, herbs or shelter selflessly and we the gainers gain non ending things from them thanklessly and cut them for our greed of one or the other things. Trees are priceless… They never demand anything from us in return of their services, even then we don’t care. Trees work endlessly without a second’s break. They absorb the most harmful carbon dioxide gas and in return provide us the pure oxygen which is our life which indirectly helps in slowing down the global warming effect. Trees cool hot days and keep warm at nights. Deforestation is normal these days, thus creating many environmental problems such as it can lead to environmental imbalance, pollution, global warming, soil erosion etc. The forest cover of the whole world has drastically depleted over a period of time owing to the human needs and activities. It is the time to save them for our own future otherwise one day will come when it will become very difficult in the treeless polluted disease causing country. One acre of forest absorbs six tons of carbon dioxide and puts out four tons of oxygen. This is enough to meet the annual needs of 18 people. -U.S. Department of Agriculture.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Barter system: Before there was money, there was barter. In barter, people exchange goods and services directly in exchange of goods and services offered by others. An individual possessing a material object of value, such as an animal, a measure of grain or farmed produce, could exchange that object for another object perceived to have equivalent value. In ancient history, all forms of goods were used in barter. Items include amber, beads, eggs, chicken, corn, rice, hoes, ivory, leather, pigs and even oxen. The list goes on. However, barter was a rather cumbersome form of trade and an ineffective way to exchange goods and services. The capacity to carry out ideal transactions is severely hampered and restricted since it is dependent on a coincidence of “wants” from both parties. The person who has a chicken to barter for some beads may not find a person with the beads who is looking for a chicken. There is no common medium of exchange in which tradable commodities can be converted into or a standardized system of value applied to those commodities. Imagine getting paid in chickens, pigs or oxen today. Try exchanging the pigs or the ox for a train ticket home or food at the supermarket. It would be utter chaos. As civilization grows, the barter system became too clumsy and was discarded in favor of other forms of currency.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: BOOMERANGS: Probably the most interesting of the various weapons of savages is the boomerang of the native Australians. The reason is its apparently paradoxical behaviour. Simple as it looks, it is credited with mysterious , and indeed almost miraculous , properties. Why? Because it is said to be able to describe wonderful curves in the air; to hit an object aimed at (a bird, say) and return to the thrower; to fly round a tree and return on the other side; to come back, circle round the thrower and fall behind him. Now whether the original Australian boomerangs can do all this, or even part of it, is questionable. Their boomerangs are almost roughly curved sticks, effective as missiles, but certainly not able to do all that they are said to do. Many travellers to Australia have decided that the returning boomerang does not exist, but this is certainly not so. Boomerangs can be made that will perform all except one of these feats: they cannot be made to hit the target and return to the hunter, unless the hit is so slight that it does not affect the course of the implement. There are many types of Boomerang but the best is probably the following. A thin piece of hard tough wood is left flat on one side but rounded on the other. It has sharpened edges, rounded ends, and is bent in the middle in its own plane at about 120 degree. The length is 2-2 ½ feet, the greatest thickness ½ inch, and the greatest breadth 1 ½ inches. It can be steamed and bent to the required angle, or made from two pieces of wood joined together, but the former is preferable. This boomerang is held in one hand and thrown horizontally (or nearly so) in such a way that it rotates rapidly. Now consider the effect of the sides of the boomerang. We make one side flat and the other round. If we throw this type in such a way that the rounded side is uppermost, it will rise much more easily. It has considerable lifting power, even when it is moving horizontally without any angle of inclination to its line of flight.

You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Disparity among sharing of resources: There is big divide in the world as North and South, the more developed countries and less developed countries, the haves and the have not’s. The more developed countries have only 22% of world’s population, but they use 88% of its natural resources, 73% of its energy and command 85% of its income. In turn, they contribute a very big proportion to its pollution. These countries include USA, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and Western European Countries. The less developed countries on the other hand, have very low or moderate industrial growth, have 78% of the world’s population and use about 12% of natural resources and 27% of energy. Their income is merely 15% of global income. the gap between the two is increasing with time due to sharp increase in population in the less developed countries The rich have grown richer while the poor have stayed poor or gone even poorer. Thus, the solution to this problem is to have more equitable distribution of resources and wealth. We cannot expect the poor countries to stop growth in order to check pollution because development brings employment and the main problem of these countries is to tackle poverty. A global consensus has to be reached for more balanced distribution of the basic resources like safe drinking water, food, fuel etc.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Having a role model is healthy and helps serve as an inspiration to a child. Importance of role models in a child’s life is that they can help a child aim high and work to achieve goals. But it is important that a child chooses a good role model, a person who has overcome adversity in his own life. A role model does not have to be someone famous. It could be a Little League Coach, a grandparent, teacher, or neighbour. Often a person who actually interacts with a child makes a better role model than a sports or movie star. A role model can have a positive impact upon a child's life in various ways. When we are growing up we look to our role models for inspiration and use this as a blueprint for how we should behave when we’re older. What all makes someone a role model? Is it only the characteristics they have or the behavior or their success? Role models show passion for their work and have the capacity to infect others with their passion. Role models live their values in the world. Children admire people who act in ways that support their beliefs. It helps them understand how their own values are part of who they are and how they might seek fulfilling roles as adults. Children develop as the result of many experiences and relationships. Role models play an important role in inspiring kids to learn, overcome obstacles, and understand that positive values can be lived each day. Whether you are a parent, grandparent, aunt, uncle, teacher, civic leader, clergy member, sports coach, after-school program leader, or a person who just happens into a child’s life, you have the ability to inspire!

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: The word Pharaoh refers to the title of the ancient Egyptian kings. It also means the “great house” and refers to royal palace. They were the god kings who ruled between 3150 B.C and 30 B.C. The ancient Egyptian pharaohs were both divine deities and mortal rulers. There were around 30+ dynasties in ancient Egyptian history. During a span of 300 years, around 170 rulers reigned over the great land of Egypt. Inheritance of the throne of Egypt was usually passed from a father to his eldest son whereas in many cases this line of kingship was interrupted by murder, pandemonium and mysterious disappearances. Also, if the only heir was a woman, her husband could become the next Pharaoh. Each time a new family took control of the throne, a new kingdom began in the history of the nation. Therefore, the rulers often intermarried with daughters, brothers to ensure that the throne remains within the family. Pharaoh used to show his/her kingship by wearing a crown or headdress with the uraeus (cobra) over the forehead. Sometimes, she/he had a bull’s tail coming from his/her belt to show personal power and also wore a false beard which was a sign of divinity.

template.description: Bats are winged mammals. They are the only mammals that can fly. They are also called nocturnal animals. They vary in size from mega bats to micro bats. The largest bats are the flying foxes found in Africa, India, Australia and Malaysia

template.description: Ms. Green was untrained for office work. Bearing this in mind, one thing was surprising. She coped most efficiently with all her duties as personal secretary to the chairman. template.description: The South Choir Aisle of Peterborough Cathedral contains some very fine marble effigies of former abbots of the monastery. It is also the site of the tomb of Mary, Queen of Scots. Her body rested beneath the choir for twenty five years. In 1612, it was removed to Westminster by order of her son, James the First.

template.description: British Railways came into being in 1948. This happened on the nationalization of rail transport. The labour government did this. The great Western railway was third and last was the London and north Eastern Railway.

You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Today, we can speak to people around the world almost anytime and anywhere. It wasn't like this before and it was made possible in part by cell phones. This is how cell phones came in picture. The Detroit Police Department began using mobile radios in their police cars. They used them to talk between cars, but it didn't work very well. The government used most radio frequencies for itself, but the air waves were still clogged up. By the 1940's most government agencies, as well as the rich people, had mobile radios. They used them while they were on the go to talk to others. A car phone service was opened between Boston and New York, but this service was a failure, too. The second attempt at car phones was a success. The equipment was large and heavy, but it worked, and that was an improvement over the past. AT & T proposed splitting phone service into different areas across the cities. These areas were called "cells". Dr. Martin Cooper invented a portable hand-held phone that didn't need to be powered through a car. He was the first person to make a mobile phone call. It took ten years for Dr. Cooper’s technology to become available to the public. The first public cell phones were put out by Motorola with a new design where the mouth piece flipped over the top of the keypad. It was the first flip phone. Developers in Europe came up with a way to send written messages over the phone. It was called texting. The smart phone could send/ receive emails, messages, but it didn't have a speaker or microphone which further needed a headset to work. A company called Sanyo made a phone that could snap pictures Later, Apple released its first I-phone and it changed the cellular industry. It featured a touch screen and allowed users to do almost anything they could do from a home computer, which basically changed the way people lived.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Fruits provide many essential nutrients that a human needs. They are naturally low in calories, sodium and fat with zero cholesterol. Fruits include the following nutrients: a. Potassium – It helps in combating high blood pressure which is a risk factor for heart disease. It may also reduce the risk of developing kidney stones and help to decrease bone loss. b.Dietary fiber – It helps reduce blood cholesterol levels and may lower risk of heart disease, obesity and type 2diabetes and is also important for proper bowel function. c. Vitamin C – It is important for growth and repair of all body tissues and keeps teeth and gums healthy. It provides antioxidant defense against infection and disease. d. Foliate (folic acid) – It Helps the body form red blood cells and helps in reducing the risk of birth defects. Fiber-rich fruit satisfies your hunger with fewer calories, helping you to maintain a healthy body weight. Fruits are a source of phytonutrients or compounds that naturally occur only in plants and are associated with a wide range of potential health benefits. Phytonutrients work synergistically with the vitamins, minerals and fiber in whole fruits to help reduce disease risk.

question.instruction: You will hear a lecture. After listening to the lecture, in 10 seconds, please speak into the microphone and retell what you have just heard from the lecture in your own words. You will have 40 seconds to give your response.

template.transcript: Renowned American writer Elizabeth Gilbert is famous the world over for her best-selling memoir “ EAT PRAY LOVE”. Gilbert's life witnessed complete metamorphosis soon after she embarked on a year long journey to Italy, India and Bali. In her own words, the experience in each of these countries helped her understand the importance of different aspects of life. Gilbert's anecdotes from Italy describe how 'pleasure' in its purest form can be found in the simplest things of life. During her four months in Italy, Gilbert visited various places, each of which had its own significance. Her time in Naples allowed her to understand the pleasures of pure indulgence. From her constant visits to the delectable Pizzerias to her time spent on the beautiful streets of Rome, Gilbert understood how one's life needs to be appreciated. There are a few things India is known for across the globe. Besides the Taj Mahal, Kamasutra and Yoga, this beautiful South Asian country draws attention for its centuries-old spirituality. Gilbert, fresh off her pleasures in Italy, arrived in India in search of the same spirituality which she had heard of at a Yoga retreat back in New York. The Ashram life is an experience of selfless devotion and meditation, all of which pave the road to Nirvana. When you have experienced both pleasure and spirituality in its purest form, it is crucial to learn to strike a balance between both. So, Gilbert's next destination had to be a place where she could understand how she can effectively connect and disconnect with the worldly pleasures in order to find the true meaning of healthy and balanced life. So she chose a place famous beyond the beaches, culture and spirituality; Bali. What she found there though was more than what she went there for. She learnt that it is the strength of positivity that helps one to get past the negative experiences in life and overcome the fears to find true love and happiness. Eat Pray Love is a collection of memoirs that transcends the barriers of age, religion and race to allow an individual to discover the true meaning of love, pleasure, spirituality and balance in life.
